packagelist.title: 1. Expedo -  FT or PT Employment Contract  (Award)
packagelist.documentTypeName: FT or PT Employment Contract (Award Covered)
packagelist.documentFileName: 1. Expedo -  FT or PT Employment Contract  (Award).docx
packagelist.questions:
[{"title":"Employment Type","header":"On what basis (either full-time or part-time) will the employee be employed?","guidance":"","questions":[{"name":"EmploymentType","label":"Employment Type","type":"Dropdown","options":[{"id":1,"name":"Full-time"},{"id":4,"name":"Part-time"}]}]},{"title":"Employee Award","header":"Insert the Modern Award that will apply to the Employee","guidance":"

To determine which modern award applies, we recommend you review the coverage provisions set out in each of the Awards.  Generally, coverage provisions appear at clause 4.

Some of the frequently applicable modern awards are:

    1. Clerks Private Sector Award 2010
    2. Manufacturing and Associated Industries Award 2010
    3. Hospitality Industry (General) Award 2010
    4. General Retail Industry Award 2010
    5. Cleaning Services Award 2010
A full list and copies of the modern awards are available on the Fair Work Commission website at https://www.fwc.gov.au/awards-and-agreements/awards/modern-awards/modern-awards-list or the Fair Work Ombudsman website at https://www.fairwork.gov.au/awards-and-agreements/awards/list-of-awards

Should you require assistance determining the Award which applies to your business and your employee, please contact Holding Redlich.

","questions":[{"name":"Award","label":"Award","type":"custom","options":[]}]},{"title":"Employee Classification","header":"Insert the employee's classification under the Modern Award","guidance":"

The classifications are generally set out in a clause dealing with minimum rates of pay and/or in a schedule to the modern award. Typically, the classifications are based on the employees duties and skill.

Should you require assistance determining the appropriate classification for your employee, please contact Holding Redlich.

","questions":[{"name":"Classification","label":"Classification","type":"custom","options":[]}]},{"title":"Annual Salary","header":"Insert the employees Annual Base Salary (insert amount, exclusive of superannuation).","guidance":null,"questions":[{"name":"AnnualSalary","label":"Annual Salary","type":"Number"}]},{"title":"Probationary Period","header":"Will the employee have a probationary period, if so, for how long?","guidance":"

Guidance: If you do not require a probationary period, insert “Not Applicable”. Otherwise, we recommend selecting a period of time in which you can adequately assess whether the employee can perform the role (i.e., 1 month, 3 months or 6 months)

Caution: If the employee is covered by a modern award and has completed a minimum period of 6 months continuous service, they may be eligible to bring an unfair dismissal claim. For this reason, we recommend that the probationary period be for a maximum of 6 months. Should you wish to have a longer probationary period, or extend the probationary period, including for performance reasons, we recommend that you seek legal advice.

","questions":[{"name":"ProbationaryPeriod","label":"Probationary Period","type":"Custom"}]},{"title":"Hours of work","header":"How many hours will the employee be contracted to work each week?","guidance":"

Guidance: For a part-time employee, the contracted hours of work must be less than 38 hours per week.

","questions":[{"name":"HoursOfWork","label":"Hours of Work","type":"Number"}],"dependency":"EmploymentType","dependencyValue":"4"},{"title":"Manager","header":"Insert name of the person (and/or the position title) to which the Employee will report","guidance":"

Guidance: The contract also provides that the employer may direct that the employer report to other persons from time to time.

","questions":[{"name":"Manager","label":"Manager","type":"Text"}]},{"title":"Location of work","header":"Insert the location/s (address) where the employee will perform the work","guidance":"

Guidance: The contract also provides that you may direct your employee to perform work at other locations from time to time.

","questions":[{"name":"Location","label":"Location of Work","type":"Textarea"}]},{"title":"Schedule of work","header":"On what days and times must the employee perform their work (i.e., Monday to Friday, 8.30am to 5.00pm)","guidance":"

Guidance: The contract also provides that you may direct your employee to perform work at other times and on other days from time to time. This may include work on the weekend or after-hours.

","questions":[{"name":"ScheduleOfWork","label":"Schedule of Work","type":"Custom"}]},{"title":"Remuneration","header":"Remuneration","guidance":"

Guidance: Option A

If you select Option A, the annual base salary does not compensate for any overtime, allowances, penalties and loadings. You will need to pay overtime, allowances, penalties and loadings when an employee is entitled to these payments.

Guidance: Option B

If you select Option B, you will need to determine an annual base salary which is “grossed up” (loaded) to include the overtime, allowances, penalties and loadings which the employee is likely to be entitled to each year.

At the completion of each year of employment, you should conduct a reconciliation to ensure that the employee has been paid their minimum entitlements over the preceding 12 month period.

","questions":[{"name":"Remuneration","label":"Remuneration","type":"Dropdown","options":[{"id":1,"name":"Option A"},{"id":2,"name":"Option B"}]}]},{"title":"Salary frequency","header":"How frequently will the base salary and any other payments be paid to the employee? E.g., fortnightly/monthly.","guidance":"

Caution: Some modern awards have clauses dealing with the frequency of payment of wages. The frequency basis set out in this employment contract should be consistent with any requirements under the applicable modern award. 

Guidance: Should a modern award set out the frequency of payments, we recommend inserting the applicable frequency period or “In accordance with the Modern Award”

","questions":[{"name":"SalaryFrequency","label":"Salary frequency","type":"Dropdown","options":[{"id":1,"name":"Weekly"},{"id":2,"name":"Fortnightly"},{"id":3,"name":"Monthly"}]}]},{"title":"Car allowance","header":"Will the employee have a car allowance paid in addition to the Annual Base Salary?","guidance":"

Guidance:  If the employee is entitled to a car allowance under the applicable modern award, and you are paying the employee a grossed-up Annual Base Salary (i.e. the Annual Base Salary compensates the employee for the car allowance entitlement), select NO as this clause provides an entitlement to a payment in addition to the Annual Base Salary.

","questions":[{"name":"HasCarAllowance","label":"Car Allowance","type":"Dropdown","options":[{"id":1,"name":"Yes"},{"id":2,"name":"No"}]}]},{"title":"Car allowance amount","header":"What is the amount of the car allowance?","guidance":"

Guidance:  Some modern awards have clauses which provide for a car allowance. Should the modern award which applies to your employee contain a clause providing a car allowance, and unless you wish to pay a more generous allowance than under the modern award, we recommend that you refer to the car allowance amount as “Calculated in accordance with the Modern Award”.

Typically, this would be expressed as an annual figure. However, this figure could be “per kilometre”, per fortnight or per month.

","questions":[{"name":"CarAllowance","label":"Car Allowance Amount","type":"Custom"}],"dependency":"HasCarAllowance","dependencyValue":"1"},{"title":"Notice period","header":"How much notice will either party be required to provide to the other party if they wish to terminate the employment?","guidance":"

Caution: The National Employment Standards (NES) set out in the Fair Work Act 2009 (Cth) specify the minimum notice period an employer is required to provide of termination.  This will range from between 1-5 weeks, depending on the employee’s length of service and age. We set out the NES notice requirements below:

Employee’s period of continuous service with the employer at the send of the day notice is given Minimum period of notice Minimum period of notice where employee is over 45 years old
Not more than one year1 week1 week
More than one year but not more than 2 years2 weeks2 weeks
At least 2 years but not more than 3 years2 weeks3 weeks
More than 3 years but not more than 5 years3 weeks4 weeks
More than 5 years4 weeks5 weeks

Some enterprise agreements may also deal with the notice that an employee must give to terminate their employment.

","questions":[{"name":"NoticePeriod","label":"Notice period","type":"Custom"}]},{"title":"Access to intranet","header":"Will the employee have access to a copy of the Award and the NES on the Company's intranet?","guidance":"

Guidance: There is no strict legal requirement for an employer to provide access to the modern award or the NES on their intranet site.  However, at a minimum, some modern awards have clauses which require the employer to provide or display a copy of the modern award at the workplace.

","questions":[{"name":"AccessToIntranet","label":"Access to intranet","type":"Dropdown","options":[{"id":1,"name":"Yes"},{"id":2,"name":"No"}]}]},{"title":"Commission scheme","header":"Will the employee be entitled to participate in a company commission scheme (i.e., to receive commission payments based on sales)?","guidance":"

If the employee may be eligible to participate in a Company commission scheme, we recommend that the contract of employment includes a clause dealing with the employee’s eligibility to participate.

","questions":[{"name":"CommissionScheme","label":"Commission scheme","type":"Dropdown","options":[{"id":1,"name":"Yes"},{"id":2,"name":"No"}]}]},{"title":"Bonus scheme","header":"Will the employee be entitled to participate in a company bonus scheme?","guidance":"

Guidance: If the employee may be eligible to participate in a bonus scheme, we recommend that the contract of employment includes a clause dealing with the employee’s eligibility to participate in that scheme. This clause will provide the employer with the maximum flexibility in how it offers a bonus payment to employees, by way of expressly stating that the bonus is a discretionary payment and carving out any contractual entitlement to a bonus.  This is important because in many cases there may be reasons why you may not be able to pay some or all of the bonus payment, including if the bonus is dependent on the profitability of the company. 

","questions":[{"name":"BonusScheme","label":"Bonus scheme","type":"Dropdown","options":[{"id":1,"name":"Yes"},{"id":2,"name":"No"}]}]},{"title":"Post-employment restraint","header":"Do you require any post-employment restraints?","guidance":"

Guidance:–We recommend post-employment restraints where a business has a ‘legitimate business interest to protect’.  A legitimate interest may be confidential information, client or supplier connections or goodwill, among other things.

A valid and enforceable post-employment restraint clause will typically prevent employees from:

    1. Poaching clients;
    2. Providing services to clients
    3. Poaching staff; and
    4. Providing their services to any competing businesses,

following the termination of their employment for a specified period of time in a specified geographic area.

Enforceability: In Australia the common law doctrine of restraint of trade operates only where it does not conflict with the Competition and Consumer Act 2010.  The common law doctrine of restraint of trade renders provisions which impose restrictions on a person's freedom to engage in trade or employment void and therefore unenforceable at common law unless they are demonstrated to bereasonable. & nbsp; The provision must be reasonable both in the interests of the parties and in the interests of the public.& nbsp; A court will consider the reasonableness of a restraint by considering whether it is \"reasonably necessary\" to protect the employer's legitimate business interests e.g. customer connection, confidential information, goodwill and staff connection.  What is reasonable will depend upon the subject matter of the restraint, the time and area of its operation, the nature of the Company's business and the industry in which the Company operates, the relationship of the employee to the Company's clients and customers, and the nature of the work performed by the employee.

If you wish to include a post-employment restraint in your contract of employment, you will need to tailor the period and geographic application of the restraint to each particular employee, in the following section. 

We recommend that you seek legal advice should you have a special business interest to protect.

","questions":[{"name":"PostEmploymentRestraints","label":"Post-employment restraint","type":"Dropdown","options":[{"id":1,"name":"Yes"},{"id":2,"name":"No"}]}]},{"title":"Restraint Area","header":"Confirm the following post-employment restraints, or otherwise amend if required.","guidance":"

Guidance: A post-employment restraint must be found by a Court to be “reasonable” in order to be enforced.  One of the factors which will be relevant to the Court to determine the reasonableness of the restraint is the restraint period and the geographic application of the restraint.

In New South Wales the Restraint of Trade Act 1976 (NSW) applies.  New South Wales is the only jurisdiction in Australia which includes particular rules dealing with restraint of trade clauses.  In New South Wales, under the Act, the Supreme Court of New South Wales can ‘read down’ an invalid restraint of trade clause, but only if it concludes that by reading down the clause, the application of the clause will no longer be against public policy. 

In all other Australian States and Territories it is important to have a cascading clause. This contract contains a cascading clause.

The restraint provision of the contract of employment is drafted as a cascading clause, meaning if one or more restraints are found unreasonable, others may nevertheless survive. 

At its highest, this clause will stop employees from providing services to one of the Company’s competitors or clients for the maximum period over the maximum area throughout Australia after an employee’s employment with the company ends.  This will be the case, irrespective of the reason for which the employment ends.  However, if the Court considers the maximum period and area unreasonable, it may nevertheless find a shorter period or smaller reasonable and therefore enforceable.  It is therefore important to provide cascading options for the Court to consider.

The Company will need to tailor the period of the restraint to each particular employee.  That is, what is the reasonable period of time after the termination of the employee's employment during which the employee is not able to poach clients or staff and provide services to clients.

","questions":[{"name":"ConfirmRestraintArea","label":"Restraint Area","type":"Radio","options":[{"id":1,"name":"Australia and New Zealand"},{"id":2,"name":"Australia"},{"id":3,"name":"State or Territory in which you are located on termination"},{"id":4,"name":"City in which you are located on termination"}]}],"dependency":"PostEmploymentRestraints","dependencyValue":"1"},{"title":"Restraint Period","header":"Confirm the following post-employment restraints, or otherwise amend if required.","guidance":"

Guidance: A post-employment restraint must be found by a Court to be “reasonable” in order to be enforced.  One of the factors which will be relevant to the Court to determine the reasonableness of the restraint is the restraint period and the geographic application of the restraint.

In New South Wales the Restraint of Trade Act 1976 (NSW) applies.  New South Wales is the only jurisdiction in Australia which includes particular rules dealing with restraint of trade clauses.  In New South Wales, under the Act, the Supreme Court of New South Wales can ‘read down’ an invalid restraint of trade clause, but only if it concludes that by reading down the clause, the application of the clause will no longer be against public policy. 

In all other Australian States and Territories it is important to have a cascading clause. This contract contains a cascading clause.

The restraint provision of the contract of employment is drafted as a cascading clause, meaning if one or more restraints are found unreasonable, others may nevertheless survive. 

At its highest, this clause will stop employees from providing services to one of the Company’s competitors or clients for the maximum period over the maximum area throughout Australia after an employee’s employment with the company ends.  This will be the case, irrespective of the reason for which the employment ends.  However, if the Court considers the maximum period and area unreasonable, it may nevertheless find a shorter period or smaller reasonable and therefore enforceable.  It is therefore important to provide cascading options for the Court to consider.

The Company will need to tailor the period of the restraint to each particular employee.  That is, what is the reasonable period of time after the termination of the employee's employment during which the employee is not able to poach clients or staff and provide services to clients.

","questions":[{"name":"ConfirmRestraintPeriod","label":"Restraint Period","type":"Radio","options":[{"id":1,"name":"12 months"},{"id":2,"name":"9 months"},{"id":3,"name":"6 months"},{"id":4,"name":"3 months"}]}],"dependency":"PostEmploymentRestraints","dependencyValue":"1"}]

","questions":[{"name":"ScheduleOfWork","label":"Schedule of Work","type":"Custom"}]},{"title":"Salary frequency","header":"How frequently will the base salary and any other payments be paid to the employee? E.g., fortnightly/monthly.","guidance":"

Caution: Some modern awards have clauses dealing with the frequency of payment of wages. The frequency basis set out in this employment contract should be consistent with any requirements under the applicable modern award. 

Guidance: Should a modern award set out the frequency of payments, we recommend inserting the applicable frequency period or “In accordance with the Modern Award”

","questions":[{"name":"SalaryFrequency","label":"Salary frequency","type":"Dropdown","options":[{"id":1,"name":"Weekly"},{"id":2,"name":"Fortnightly"},{"id":3,"name":"Monthly"}]}]},{"title":"Car allowance","header":"Will the employee have a car allowance paid in addition to the Annual Base Salary?","guidance":"

Guidance:  If the employee is entitled to a car allowance under the applicable modern award, and you are paying the employee a grossed-up Annual Base Salary (i.e. the Annual Base Salary compensates the employee for the car allowance entitlement), select NO as this clause provides an entitlement to a payment in addition to the Annual Base Salary.

","questions":[{"name":"HasCarAllowance","label":"Car Allowance","type":"Dropdown","options":[{"id":1,"name":"Yes"},{"id":2,"name":"No"}]}]},{"title":"Car allowance amount","header":"What is the amount of the car allowance?","guidance":"

Guidance:  Some modern awards have clauses which provide for a car allowance. Should the modern award which applies to your employee contain a clause providing a car allowance, and unless you wish to pay a more generous allowance than under the modern award, we recommend that you refer to the car allowance amount as “Calculated in accordance with the Modern Award”.

Typically, this would be expressed as an annual figure. However, this figure could be “per kilometre”, per fortnight or per month.

","questions":[{"name":"CarAllowance","label":"Car Allowance Amount","type":"Custom"}],"dependency":"HasCarAllowance","dependencyValue":"1"},{"title":"Notice period","header":"How much notice will either party be required to provide to the other party if they wish to terminate the employment?","guidance":"

Caution: The National Employment Standards (NES) set out in the Fair Work Act 2009 (Cth) specify the minimum notice period an employer is required to provide of termination.  This will range from between 1-5 weeks, depending on the employee’s length of service and age. We set out the NES notice requirements below:

Employee’s period of continuous service with the employer at the send of the day notice is given Minimum period of notice Minimum period of notice where employee is over 45 years old
Not more than one year1 week1 week
More than one year but not more than 2 years2 weeks2 weeks
At least 2 years but not more than 3 years2 weeks3 weeks
More than 3 years but not more than 5 years3 weeks4 weeks
More than 5 years4 weeks5 weeks

Some enterprise agreements may also deal with the notice that an employee must give to terminate their employment.

","questions":[{"name":"NoticePeriod","label":"Notice period","type":"Custom"}]},{"title":"Commission scheme","header":"Will the employee be entitled to participate in a company commission scheme (i.e., to receive commission payments based on sales)?","guidance":"

If the employee may be eligible to participate in a Company commission scheme, we recommend that the contract of employment includes a clause dealing with the employee’s eligibility to participate.

","questions":[{"name":"CommissionScheme","label":"Commission scheme","type":"Dropdown","options":[{"id":1,"name":"Yes"},{"id":2,"name":"No"}]}]},{"title":"Bonus scheme","header":"Will the employee be entitled to participate in a company bonus scheme?","guidance":"

Guidance: If the employee may be eligible to participate in a bonus scheme, we recommend that the contract of employment includes a clause dealing with the employee’s eligibility to participate in that scheme. This clause will provide the employer with the maximum flexibility in how it offers a bonus payment to employees, by way of expressly stating that the bonus is a discretionary payment and carving out any contractual entitlement to a bonus.  This is important because in many cases there may be reasons why you may not be able to pay some or all of the bonus payment, including if the bonus is dependent on the profitability of the company. 

","questions":[{"name":"BonusScheme","label":"Bonus scheme","type":"Dropdown","options":[{"id":1,"name":"Yes"},{"id":2,"name":"No"}]}]},{"title":"Director","header":"Will the employee be required to act as a director of the Employer or a related entity of the Employer?","guidance":"

Guidance: If you may require you employee to act as a director:

this option will insert a clause which specifies that the employee will not be entitled to receive additional remuneration for the directorship.  A separate clause will also provide that if the employee’s employment terminates while the employee is still a director, the employee must also resign from the directorship.

","questions":[{"name":"Director","label":"Director","type":"Dropdown","options":[{"id":1,"name":"Yes"},{"id":2,"name":"No"}]}]},{"title":"Post-employment restraint","header":"Do you require any post-employment restraints?","guidance":"

Guidance:–We recommend post-employment restraints where a business has a ‘legitimate business interest to protect’.  A legitimate interest may be confidential information, client or supplier connections or goodwill, among other things.

A valid and enforceable post-employment restraint clause will typically prevent employees from:

    1. Poaching clients;
    2. Providing services to clients
    3. Poaching staff; and
    4. Providing their services to any competing businesses,

following the termination of their employment for a specified period of time in a specified geographic area.

Enforceability: In Australia the common law doctrine of restraint of trade operates only where it does not conflict with the Competition and Consumer Act 2010.  The common law doctrine of restraint of trade renders provisions which impose restrictions on a person's freedom to engage in trade or employment void and therefore unenforceable at common law unless they are demonstrated to bereasonable. & nbsp; The provision must be reasonable both in the interests of the parties and in the interests of the public.& nbsp; A court will consider the reasonableness of a restraint by considering whether it is \"reasonably necessary\" to protect the employer's legitimate business interests e.g. customer connection, confidential information, goodwill and staff connection.  What is reasonable will depend upon the subject matter of the restraint, the time and area of its operation, the nature of the Company's business and the industry in which the Company operates, the relationship of the employee to the Company's clients and customers, and the nature of the work performed by the employee.

If you wish to include a post-employment restraint in your contract of employment, you will need to tailor the period and geographic application of the restraint to each particular employee, in the following section. 

We recommend that you seek legal advice should you have a special business interest to protect.

","questions":[{"name":"PostEmploymentRestraints","label":"Post-employment restraint","type":"Dropdown","options":[{"id":1,"name":"Yes"},{"id":2,"name":"No"}]}]},{"title":"Restraint Area","header":"Confirm the following post-employment restraints, or otherwise amend if required.","guidance":"

Guidance: A post-employment restraint must be found by a Court to be “reasonable” in order to be enforced.  One of the factors which will be relevant to the Court to determine the reasonableness of the restraint is the restraint period and the geographic application of the restraint.

In New South Wales the Restraint of Trade Act 1976 (NSW) applies.  New South Wales is the only jurisdiction in Australia which includes particular rules dealing with restraint of trade clauses.  In New South Wales, under the Act, the Supreme Court of New South Wales can ‘read down’ an invalid restraint of trade clause, but only if it concludes that by reading down the clause, the application of the clause will no longer be against public policy. 

In all other Australian States and Territories it is important to have a cascading clause. This contract contains a cascading clause.

The restraint provision of the contract of employment is drafted as a cascading clause, meaning if one or more restraints are found unreasonable, others may nevertheless survive. 

At its highest, this clause will stop employees from providing services to one of the Company’s competitors or clients for the maximum period over the maximum area throughout Australia after an employee’s employment with the company ends.  This will be the case, irrespective of the reason for which the employment ends.  However, if the Court considers the maximum period and area unreasonable, it may nevertheless find a shorter period or smaller reasonable and therefore enforceable.  It is therefore important to provide cascading options for the Court to consider.

The Company will need to tailor the period of the restraint to each particular employee.  That is, what is the reasonable period of time after the termination of the employee's employment during which the employee is not able to poach clients or staff and provide services to clients.

To determine which modern award applies, we recommend you review the coverage provisions set out in each of the Awards.  Generally, coverage provisions appear at clause 4.

Employee’s period of continuous service with the employer at the send of the day notice is given Minimum period of notice Minimum period of notice where employee is over 45 years old
Not more than one year1 week1 week
More than one year but not more than 2 years2 weeks2 weeks
At least 2 years but not more than 3 years2 weeks3 weeks
More than 3 years but not more than 5 years3 weeks4 weeks
More than 5 years4 weeks5 weeks

Some enterprise agreements may also deal with the notice that an employee must give to terminate their employment.

","questions":[{"name":"NoticePeriod","label":"Notice period","type":"Custom"}]},{"title":"Access to intranet","header":"Will the employee have access to a copy of the Award and the NES on the Company's intranet?","guidance":"

Guidance: There is no strict legal requirement for an employer to provide access to the modern award or the NES on their intranet site.  However, at a minimum, some modern awards have clauses which require the employer to provide or display a copy of the modern award at the workplace.

","questions":[{"name":"AccessToIntranet","label":"Access to intranet","type":"Dropdown","options":[{"id":1,"name":"Yes"},{"id":2,"name":"No"}]}]},{"title":"Commission scheme","header":"Will the employee be entitled to participate in a company commission scheme (i.e., to receive commission payments based on sales)?","guidance":"

If the employee may be eligible to participate in a Company commission scheme, we recommend that the contract of employment includes a clause dealing with the employee’s eligibility to participate.

","questions":[{"name":"CommissionScheme","label":"Commission scheme","type":"Dropdown","options":[{"id":1,"name":"Yes"},{"id":2,"name":"No"}]}]},{"title":"Bonus scheme","header":"Will the employee be entitled to participate in a company bonus scheme?","guidance":"

Guidance: If the employee may be eligible to participate in a bonus scheme, we recommend that the contract of employment includes a clause dealing with the employee’s eligibility to participate in that scheme. This clause will provide the employer with the maximum flexibility in how it offers a bonus payment to employees, by way of expressly stating that the bonus is a discretionary payment and carving out any contractual entitlement to a bonus.  This is important because in many cases there may be reasons why you may not be able to pay some or all of the bonus payment, including if the bonus is dependent on the profitability of the company. 

","questions":[{"name":"BonusScheme","label":"Bonus scheme","type":"Dropdown","options":[{"id":1,"name":"Yes"},{"id":2,"name":"No"}]}]},{"title":"Post-employment restraint","header":"Do you require any post-employment restraints?","guidance":"

Guidance:–We recommend post-employment restraints where a business has a ‘legitimate business interest to protect’.  A legitimate interest may be confidential information, client or supplier connections or goodwill, among other things.

A valid and enforceable post-employment restraint clause will typically prevent employees from:

    1. Poaching clients;
    2. Providing services to clients
    3. Poaching staff; and
    4. Providing their services to any competing businesses,

following the termination of their employment for a specified period of time in a specified geographic area.

Enforceability: In Australia the common law doctrine of restraint of trade operates only where it does not conflict with the Competition and Consumer Act 2010.  The common law doctrine of restraint of trade renders provisions which impose restrictions on a person's freedom to engage in trade or employment void and therefore unenforceable at common law unless they are demonstrated to bereasonable. & nbsp; The provision must be reasonable both in the interests of the parties and in the interests of the public.& nbsp; A court will consider the reasonableness of a restraint by considering whether it is \"reasonably necessary\" to protect the employer's legitimate business interests e.g. customer connection, confidential information, goodwill and staff connection.  What is reasonable will depend upon the subject matter of the restraint, the time and area of its operation, the nature of the Company's business and the industry in which the Company operates, the relationship of the employee to the Company's clients and customers, and the nature of the work performed by the employee.

If you wish to include a post-employment restraint in your contract of employment, you will need to tailor the period and geographic application of the restraint to each particular employee, in the following section. 

We recommend that you seek legal advice should you have a special business interest to protect.

","questions":[{"name":"PostEmploymentRestraints","label":"Post-employment restraint","type":"Dropdown","options":[{"id":1,"name":"Yes"},{"id":2,"name":"No"}]}]},{"title":"Restraint Area","header":"Confirm the following post-employment restraints, or otherwise amend if required.","guidance":"

Guidance: A post-employment restraint must be found by a Court to be “reasonable” in order to be enforced.  One of the factors which will be relevant to the Court to determine the reasonableness of the restraint is the restraint period and the geographic application of the restraint.

In New South Wales the Restraint of Trade Act 1976 (NSW) applies.  New South Wales is the only jurisdiction in Australia which includes particular rules dealing with restraint of trade clauses.  In New South Wales, under the Act, the Supreme Court of New South Wales can ‘read down’ an invalid restraint of trade clause, but only if it concludes that by reading down the clause, the application of the clause will no longer be against public policy. 

In all other Australian States and Territories it is important to have a cascading clause. This contract contains a cascading clause.

The restraint provision of the contract of employment is drafted as a cascading clause, meaning if one or more restraints are found unreasonable, others may nevertheless survive. 

At its highest, this clause will stop employees from providing services to one of the Company’s competitors or clients for the maximum period over the maximum area throughout Australia after an employee’s employment with the company ends.  This will be the case, irrespective of the reason for which the employment ends.  However, if the Court considers the maximum period and area unreasonable, it may nevertheless find a shorter period or smaller reasonable and therefore enforceable.  It is therefore important to provide cascading options for the Court to consider.

The Company will need to tailor the period of the restraint to each particular employee.  That is, what is the reasonable period of time after the termination of the employee's employment during which the employee is not able to poach clients or staff and provide services to clients.

Guidance: If you do not require a probationary period, insert “Not Applicable”. Otherwise, we recommend selecting a period of time in which you can adequately assess whether the employee can perform the role (i.e., 1 month, 3 months or 6 months)

Caution: If the employee is covered by a modern award and has completed a minimum period of 6 months continuous service, they may be eligible to bring an unfair dismissal claim.     1. Clerks Private Sector Award 2010

If you select Option A, the annual base salary does not compensate for any overtime, allowances, penalties and loadings. You will need to pay overtime, allowances, penalties and loadings when an employee is entitled to these payments.

Guidance: Option B

If you select Option B, you will need to determine an annual base salary which is “grossed up” (loaded) to include the overtime, allowances, penalties and loadings which the employee is likely to be entitled to each year.

At the completion of each year of employment, you should conduct a reconciliation to ensure that the employee has been paid their minimum entitlements over the preceding 12 month period.

At its highest, this clause will stop employees from providing services to one of the Company’s competitors or clients for the maximum period over the maximum area throughout Australia after an employee’s employment with the company ends.  This will be the case, irrespective of the reason for which the employment ends.  However, if the Court considers the maximum period and area unreasonable, it may nevertheless find a shorter period or smaller reasonable and therefore enforceable.  It is therefore important to provide cascading options for the Court to consider.

packagelist.title: 10. Expedo- Fixed Term Employment Contract (Non-Award)
packagelist.questions:
[{"title":"Employment Type","header":"On what basis (either full-time or part-time) will the employee be employed?","guidance":"","questions":[{"name":"EmploymentType","label":"Employment Type","type":"Dropdown","options":[{"id":1,"name":"Full-time"},{"id":4,"name":"Part-time"}]}]},{"title":"Annual Salary","header":"Insert the employees Annual Base Salary (insert amount, exclusive of superannuation).","guidance":null,"questions":[{"name":"AnnualSalary","label":"Annual Salary","type":"Number"}]},{"title":"Employee's End Date","header":"Insert the end date of the employment agreement between the Employer and Employee","guidance":null,"questions":[{"name":"EndDate","label":"End Date","type":"Date"}]},{"title":"Probationary Period","header":"Will the employee have a probationary period, if so, for how long?","guidance":"

Guidance: If you do not require a probationary period, insert “Not Applicable”. Otherwise, we recommend selecting a period of time in which you can adequately assess whether the employee can perform the role (i.e., 1 month, 3 months or 6 months)

Caution: If the employee is covered by a modern award and has completed a minimum period of 6 months continuous service, they may be eligible to bring an unfair dismissal claim. For this reason, we recommend that the probationary period be for a maximum of 6 months. Should you wish to have a longer probationary period, or extend the probationary period, including for performance reasons, we recommend that you seek legal advice.

","questions":[{"name":"ProbationaryPeriod","label":"Probationary Period","type":"Custom"}]},{"title":"Hours of work","header":"How many hours will the employee be contracted to work each week?","guidance":"

Guidance: For a part-time employee, the contracted hours of work must be less than 38 hours per week.

","questions":[{"name":"HoursOfWork","label":"Hours of Work","type":"Number"}],"dependency":"EmploymentType","dependencyValue":"4"},{"title":"Manager","header":"Insert name of the person (and/or the position title) to which the Employee will report","guidance":"

Guidance: The contract also provides that the employer may direct that the employer report to other persons from time to time.

","questions":[{"name":"Manager","label":"Manager","type":"Text"}]},{"title":"Location of work","header":"Insert the location/s (address) where the employee will perform the work","guidance":"

Guidance: The contract also provides that you may direct your employee to perform work at other locations from time to time.

","questions":[{"name":"Location","label":"Location of Work","type":"Textarea"}]},{"title":"Schedule of work","header":"On what days and times must the employee perform their work (i.e., Monday to Friday, 8.30am to 5.00pm)","guidance":"

Guidance: The contract also provides that you may direct your employee to perform work at other times and on other days from time to time. This may include work on the weekend or after-hours.

","questions":[{"name":"ScheduleOfWork","label":"Schedule of Work","type":"Custom"}]},{"title":"Salary frequency","header":"How frequently will the base salary and any other payments be paid to the employee? E.g., fortnightly/monthly.","guidance":"

Caution: Some modern awards have clauses dealing with the frequency of payment of wages. The frequency basis set out in this employment contract should be consistent with any requirements under the applicable modern award. 

Guidance: Should a modern award set out the frequency of payments, we recommend inserting the applicable frequency period or “In accordance with the Modern Award”

","questions":[{"name":"SalaryFrequency","label":"Salary frequency","type":"Dropdown","options":[{"id":1,"name":"Weekly"},{"id":2,"name":"Fortnightly"},{"id":3,"name":"Monthly"}]}]},{"title":"Car allowance","header":"Will the employee have a car allowance paid in addition to the Annual Base Salary?","guidance":"

Guidance:  If the employee is entitled to a car allowance under the applicable modern award, and you are paying the employee a grossed-up Annual Base Salary (i.e. the Annual Base Salary compensates the employee for the car allowance entitlement), select NO as this clause provides an entitlement to a payment in addition to the Annual Base Salary.

","questions":[{"name":"HasCarAllowance","label":"Car Allowance","type":"Dropdown","options":[{"id":1,"name":"Yes"},{"id":2,"name":"No"}]}]},{"title":"Car allowance amount","header":"What is the amount of the car allowance?","guidance":"

Guidance:  Some modern awards have clauses which provide for a car allowance. Should the modern award which applies to your employee contain a clause providing a car allowance, and unless you wish to pay a more generous allowance than under the modern award, we recommend that you refer to the car allowance amount as “Calculated in accordance with the Modern Award”.

Typically, this would be expressed as an annual figure. However, this figure could be “per kilometre”, per fortnight or per month.

","questions":[{"name":"CarAllowance","label":"Car Allowance Amount","type":"Custom"}],"dependency":"HasCarAllowance","dependencyValue":"1"},{"title":"Commission scheme","header":"Will the employee be entitled to participate in a company commission scheme (i.e., to receive commission payments based on sales)?","guidance":"

If the employee may be eligible to participate in a Company commission scheme, we recommend that the contract of employment includes a clause dealing with the employee’s eligibility to participate.

","questions":[{"name":"CommissionScheme","label":"Commission scheme","type":"Dropdown","options":[{"id":1,"name":"Yes"},{"id":2,"name":"No"}]}]},{"title":"Bonus scheme","header":"Will the employee be entitled to participate in a company bonus scheme?","guidance":"

Guidance: If the employee may be eligible to participate in a bonus scheme, we recommend that the contract of employment includes a clause dealing with the employee’s eligibility to participate in that scheme. This clause will provide the employer with the maximum flexibility in how it offers a bonus payment to employees, by way of expressly stating that the bonus is a discretionary payment and carving out any contractual entitlement to a bonus.  This is important because in many cases there may be reasons why you may not be able to pay some or all of the bonus payment, including if the bonus is dependent on the profitability of the company. 

","questions":[{"name":"BonusScheme","label":"Bonus scheme","type":"Dropdown","options":[{"id":1,"name":"Yes"},{"id":2,"name":"No"}]}]},{"title":"Post-employment restraint","header":"Do you require any post-employment restraints?","guidance":"

Guidance:–We recommend post-employment restraints where a business has a ‘legitimate business interest to protect’.  A legitimate interest may be confidential information, client or supplier connections or goodwill, among other things.

A valid and enforceable post-employment restraint clause will typically prevent employees from:

    1. Poaching clients;
    2. Providing services to clients
    3. Poaching staff; and
    4. Providing their services to any competing businesses,

following the termination of their employment for a specified period of time in a specified geographic area.

Enforceability: In Australia the common law doctrine of restraint of trade operates only where it does not conflict with the Competition and Consumer Act 2010.  The common law doctrine of restraint of trade renders provisions which impose restrictions on a person's freedom to engage in trade or employment void and therefore unenforceable at common law unless they are demonstrated to bereasonable. & nbsp; The provision must be reasonable both in the interests of the parties and in the interests of the public.& nbsp; A court will consider the reasonableness of a restraint by considering whether it is \"reasonably necessary\" to protect the employer's legitimate business interests e.g. customer connection, confidential information, goodwill and staff connection.  What is reasonable will depend upon the subject matter of the restraint, the time and area of its operation, the nature of the Company's business and the industry in which the Company operates, the relationship of the employee to the Company's clients and customers, and the nature of the work performed by the employee.

If you wish to include a post-employment restraint in your contract of employment, you will need to tailor the period and geographic application of the restraint to each particular employee, in the following section. 

We recommend that you seek legal advice should you have a special business interest to protect.

For this reason, we recommend that the probationary period be for a maximum of 6 months. Should you wish to have a longer probationary period, or extend the probationary period, including for performance reasons, we recommend that you seek legal advice.

Guidance: For a part-time employee, the contracted hours of work must be less than 38 hours per week.

","questions":[{"name":"HoursOfWork","label":"Hours of Work","type":"Number"}],"dependency":"EmploymentType","dependencyValue":"4"},{"title":"Manager","header":"Insert name of the person (and/or the position title) to which the Employee will report","guidance":"

Guidance: The contract also provides that the employer may direct that the employer report to other persons from time to time.

","questions":[{"name":"Manager","label":"Manager","type":"Text"}]},{"title":"Location of work","header":"Insert the location/s (address) where the employee will perform the work","guidance":"

Guidance: The contract also provides that you may direct your employee to perform work at other locations from time to time.

","questions":[{"name":"Location","label":"Location of Work","type":"Textarea"}]},{"title":"Schedule of work","header":"On what days and times must the employee perform their work (i.e., Monday to Friday, 8.30am to 5.00pm)","guidance":"

Guidance: The contract also provides that you may direct your employee to perform work at other times and on other days from time to time. This may include work on the weekend or after-hours.

","questions":[{"name":"ScheduleOfWork","label":"Schedule of Work","type":"Custom"}]},{"title":"Remuneration","header":"Remuneration","guidance":"

Guidance: Option A

If you select Option A, the annual base salary does not compensate for any overtime, allowances, penalties and loadings. You will need to pay overtime, allowances, penalties and loadings when an employee is entitled to these payments.

Guidance: Option B

If you select Option B, you will need to determine an annual base salary which is “grossed up” (loaded) to include the overtime, allowances, penalties and loadings which the employee is likely to be entitled to each year.

At the completion of each year of employment, you should conduct a reconciliation to ensure that the employee has been paid their minimum entitlements over the preceding 12 month period.

","questions":[{"name":"Remuneration","label":"Remuneration","type":"Dropdown","options":[{"id":1,"name":"Option A"},{"id":2,"name":"Option B"}]}]},{"title":"Salary frequency","header":"How frequently will the base salary and any other payments be paid to the employee? E.g., fortnightly/monthly.","guidance":"

Caution: Some modern awards have clauses dealing with the frequency of payment of wages. The frequency basis set out in this employment contract should be consistent with any requirements under the applicable modern award. 

Guidance: Should a modern award set out the frequency of payments, we recommend inserting the applicable frequency period or “In accordance with the Modern Award”

","questions":[{"name":"SalaryFrequency","label":"Salary frequency","type":"Dropdown","options":[{"id":1,"name":"Weekly"},{"id":2,"name":"Fortnightly"},{"id":3,"name":"Monthly"}]}]},{"title":"Car allowance","header":"Will the employee have a car allowance paid in addition to the Annual Base Salary?","guidance":"

Guidance:  If the employee is entitled to a car allowance under the applicable modern award, and you are paying the employee a grossed-up Annual Base Salary (i.e. the Annual Base Salary compensates the employee for the car allowance entitlement), select NO as this clause provides an entitlement to a payment in addition to the Annual Base Salary.

","questions":[{"name":"HasCarAllowance","label":"Car Allowance","type":"Dropdown","options":[{"id":1,"name":"Yes"},{"id":2,"name":"No"}]}]},{"title":"Car allowance amount","header":"What is the amount of the car allowance?","guidance":"

Guidance:  Some modern awards have clauses which provide for a car allowance. Should the modern award which applies to your employee contain a clause providing a car allowance, and unless you wish to pay a more generous allowance than under the modern award, we recommend that you refer to the car allowance amount as “Calculated in accordance with the Modern Award”.

Typically, this would be expressed as an annual figure. However, this figure could be “per kilometre”, per fortnight or per month.

","questions":[{"name":"CarAllowance","label":"Car Allowance Amount","type":"Custom"}],"dependency":"HasCarAllowance","dependencyValue":"1"},{"title":"Notice period","header":"How much notice will either party be required to provide to the other party if they wish to terminate the employment?","guidance":"

Caution: The National Employment Standards (NES) set out in the Fair Work Act 2009 (Cth) specify the minimum notice period an employer is required to provide of termination.  This will range from between 1-5 weeks, depending on the employee’s length of service and age. We set out the NES notice requirements below:

Employee’s period of continuous service with the employer at the send of the day notice is given Minimum period of notice Minimum period of notice where employee is over 45 years old
Not more than one year1 week1 week
More than one year but not more than 2 years2 weeks2 weeks
At least 2 years but not more than 3 years2 weeks3 weeks
More than 3 years but not more than 5 years3 weeks4 weeks
More than 5 years4 weeks5 weeks

Some enterprise agreements may also deal with the notice that an employee must give to terminate their employment.

","questions":[{"name":"NoticePeriod","label":"Notice period","type":"Custom"}]},{"title":"Access to intranet","header":"Will you provide the employee with access to a copy of the Enterprise Agreement and the NES on the Company's intranet?","guidance":"

Guidance: There is no strict legal requirement for an employer to provide access to the enterprise agreement or the NES on their intranet site. However, some enterprise agreements may have clauses which require the employer to provide or display a copy of the enterprise agreement at the workplace.

","questions":[{"name":"AccessToIntranet","label":"Access to intranet","type":"Dropdown","options":[{"id":1,"name":"Yes"},{"id":2,"name":"No"}]}]},{"title":"Commission scheme","header":"Will the employee be entitled to participate in a company commission scheme (i.e., to receive commission payments based on sales)?","guidance":"

If the employee may be eligible to participate in a Company commission scheme, we recommend that the contract of employment includes a clause dealing with the employee’s eligibility to participate.

","questions":[{"name":"CommissionScheme","label":"Commission scheme","type":"Dropdown","options":[{"id":1,"name":"Yes"},{"id":2,"name":"No"}]}]},{"title":"Bonus scheme","header":"Will the employee be entitled to participate in a company bonus scheme?","guidance":"

Guidance: If the employee may be eligible to participate in a bonus scheme, we recommend that the contract of employment includes a clause dealing with the employee’s eligibility to participate in that scheme. This clause will provide the employer with the maximum flexibility in how it offers a bonus payment to employees, by way of expressly stating that the bonus is a discretionary payment and carving out any contractual entitlement to a bonus.  This is important because in many cases there may be reasons why you may not be able to pay some or all of the bonus payment, including if the bonus is dependent on the profitability of the company. 

","questions":[{"name":"BonusScheme","label":"Bonus scheme","type":"Dropdown","options":[{"id":1,"name":"Yes"},{"id":2,"name":"No"}]}]},{"title":"Post-employment restraint","header":"Do you require any post-employment restraints?","guidance":"

Guidance:–We recommend post-employment restraints where a business has a ‘legitimate business interest to protect’.  A legitimate interest may be confidential information, client or supplier connections or goodwill, among other things.

A valid and enforceable post-employment restraint clause will typically prevent employees from:

    1. Poaching clients;
    2. Providing services to clients
    3. Poaching staff; and
    4. Providing their services to any competing businesses,

following the termination of their employment for a specified period of time in a specified geographic area.

Enforceability: In Australia the common law doctrine of restraint of trade operates only where it does not conflict with the Competition and Consumer Act 2010.  The common law doctrine of restraint of trade renders provisions which impose restrictions on a person's freedom to engage in trade or employment void and therefore unenforceable at common law unless they are demonstrated to bereasonable. & nbsp; The provision must be reasonable both in the interests of the parties and in the interests of the public.& nbsp; A court will consider the reasonableness of a restraint by considering whether it is \"reasonably necessary\" to protect the employer's legitimate business interests e.g. customer connection, confidential information, goodwill and staff connection.  What is reasonable will depend upon the subject matter of the restraint, the time and area of its operation, the nature of the Company's business and the industry in which the Company operates, the relationship of the employee to the Company's clients and customers, and the nature of the work performed by the employee.

If you wish to include a post-employment restraint in your contract of employment, you will need to tailor the period and geographic application of the restraint to each particular employee, in the following section. 

We recommend that you seek legal advice should you have a special business interest to protect.

","questions":[{"name":"PostEmploymentRestraints","label":"Post-employment restraint","type":"Dropdown","options":[{"id":1,"name":"Yes"},{"id":2,"name":"No"}]}]},{"title":"Restraint Area","header":"Confirm the following post-employment restraints, or otherwise amend if required.","guidance":"

Guidance: A post-employment restraint must be found by a Court to be “reasonable” in order to be enforced.  One of the factors which will be relevant to the Court to determine the reasonableness of the restraint is the restraint period and the geographic application of the restraint.

In New South Wales the Restraint of Trade Act 1976 (NSW) applies.  New South Wales is the only jurisdiction in Australia which includes particular rules dealing with restraint of trade clauses.  In New South Wales, under the Act, the Supreme Court of New South Wales can ‘read down’ an invalid restraint of trade clause, but only if it concludes that by reading down the clause, the application of the clause will no longer be against public policy. 

In all other Australian States and Territories it is important to have a cascading clause. This contract contains a cascading clause.

The restraint provision of the contract of employment is drafted as a cascading clause, meaning if one or more restraints are found unreasonable, others may nevertheless survive. 

At its highest, this clause will stop employees from providing services to one of the Company’s competitors or clients for the maximum period over the maximum area throughout Australia after an employee’s employment with the company ends.  This will be the case, irrespective of the reason for which the employment ends.  However, if the Court considers the maximum period and area unreasonable, it may nevertheless find a shorter period or smaller reasonable and therefore enforceable.  It is therefore important to provide cascading options for the Court to consider.

The Company will need to tailor the period of the restraint to each particular employee.  That is, what is the reasonable period of time after the termination of the employee's employment during which the employee is not able to poach clients or staff and provide services to clients.

In New South Wales the Restraint of Trade Act 1976 (NSW) applies.  New South Wales is the only jurisdiction in Australia which includes particular rules dealing with restraint of trade clauses.  In New South Wales, under the Act, the Supreme Court of New South Wales can ‘read down’ an invalid restraint of trade clause, but only if it concludes that by reading down the clause, the application of the clause will no longer be against public policy. 

In all other Australian States and Territories it is important to have a cascading clause. This contract contains a cascading clause.

The restraint provision of the contract of employment is drafted as a cascading clause, meaning if one or more restraints are found unreasonable, others may nevertheless survive. 

At its highest, this clause will stop employees from providing services to one of the Company’s competitors or clients for the maximum period over the maximum area throughout Australia after an employee’s employment with the company ends.  This will be the case, irrespective of the reason for which the employment ends.  However, if the Court considers the maximum period and area unreasonable, it may nevertheless find a shorter period or smaller reasonable and therefore enforceable.  It is therefore important to provide cascading options for the Court to consider.

The Company will need to tailor the period of the restraint to each particular employee.  That is, what is the reasonable period of time after the termination of the employee's employment during which the employee is not able to poach clients or staff and provide services to clients.

packagelist.documentTypeName: FT or PT Employment Contract (Award Covered)
packagelist.questions:
[{"title":"Employment Type","header":"On what basis (either full-time or part-time) will the employee be employed?","guidance":"","questions":[{"name":"EmploymentType","label":"Employment Type","type":"Dropdown","options":[{"id":1,"name":"Full-time"},{"id":4,"name":"Part-time"}]}]},{"title":"Employee Award","header":"Insert the Modern Award that will apply to the Employee","guidance":"

To determine which modern award applies, we recommend you review the coverage provisions set out in each of the Awards.  Generally, coverage provisions appear at clause 4.

Some of the frequently applicable modern awards are:

    1. Clerks Private Sector Award 2010
    2. Manufacturing and Associated Industries Award 2010
    3. Hospitality Industry (General) Award 2010
    4. General Retail Industry Award 2010
    5. Cleaning Services Award 2010
A full list and copies of the modern awards are available on the Fair Work Commission website at https://www.fwc.gov.au/awards-and-agreements/awards/modern-awards/modern-awards-list or the Fair Work Ombudsman website at https://www.fairwork.gov.au/awards-and-agreements/awards/list-of-awards

Should you require assistance determining the Award which applies to your business and your employee, please contact Holding Redlich.

","questions":[{"name":"Award","label":"Award","type":"custom","options":[]}]},{"title":"Employee Classification","header":"Insert the employee's classification under the Modern Award","guidance":"

The classifications are generally set out in a clause dealing with minimum rates of pay and/or in a schedule to the modern award. Typically, the classifications are based on the employees duties and skill.

Should you require assistance determining the appropriate classification for your employee, please contact Holding Redlich.

","questions":[{"name":"Classification","label":"Classification","type":"custom","options":[]}]},{"title":"Annual Salary","header":"Insert the employees Annual Base Salary (insert amount, exclusive of superannuation).","guidance":null,"questions":[{"name":"AnnualSalary","label":"Annual Salary","type":"Number"}]},{"title":"Probationary Period","header":"Will the employee have a probationary period, if so, for how long?","guidance":"

Guidance: If you do not require a probationary period, insert “Not Applicable”. Otherwise, we recommend selecting a period of time in which you can adequately assess whether the employee can perform the role (i.e., 1 month, 3 months or 6 months)

Caution: If the employee is covered by a modern award and has completed a minimum period of 6 months continuous service, they may be eligible to bring an unfair dismissal claim. For this reason, we recommend that the probationary period be for a maximum of 6 months. Should you wish to have a longer probationary period, or extend the probationary period, including for performance reasons, we recommend that you seek legal advice.

","questions":[{"name":"ProbationaryPeriod","label":"Probationary Period","type":"Custom"}]},{"title":"Hours of work","header":"How many hours will the employee be contracted to work each week?","guidance":"

Guidance: For a part-time employee, the contracted hours of work must be less than 38 hours per week.

","questions":[{"name":"HoursOfWork","label":"Hours of Work","type":"Number"}],"dependency":"EmploymentType","dependencyValue":"4"},{"title":"Manager","header":"Insert name of the person (and/or the position title) to which the Employee will report","guidance":"

Guidance: The contract also provides that the employer may direct that the employer report to other persons from time to time.

","questions":[{"name":"Manager","label":"Manager","type":"Text"}]},{"title":"Location of work","header":"Insert the location/s (address) where the employee will perform the work","guidance":"

Guidance: The contract also provides that you may direct your employee to perform work at other locations from time to time.

","questions":[{"name":"Location","label":"Location of Work","type":"Textarea"}]},{"title":"Schedule of work","header":"On what days and times must the employee perform their work (i.e., Monday to Friday, 8.30am to 5.00pm)","guidance":"

Guidance: The contract also provides that you may direct your employee to perform work at other times and on other days from time to time. This may include work on the weekend or after-hours.

","questions":[{"name":"ScheduleOfWork","label":"Schedule of Work","type":"Custom"}]},{"title":"Remuneration","header":"Remuneration","guidance":"

Guidance: Option A

If you select Option A, the annual base salary does not compensate for any overtime, allowances, penalties and loadings. You will need to pay overtime, allowances, penalties and loadings when an employee is entitled to these payments.

Guidance: Option B

If you select Option B, you will need to determine an annual base salary which is “grossed up” (loaded) to include the overtime, allowances, penalties and loadings which the employee is likely to be entitled to each year.

At the completion of each year of employment, you should conduct a reconciliation to ensure that the employee has been paid their minimum entitlements over the preceding 12 month period.

","questions":[{"name":"Remuneration","label":"Remuneration","type":"Dropdown","options":[{"id":1,"name":"Option A"},{"id":2,"name":"Option B"}]}]},{"title":"Salary frequency","header":"How frequently will the base salary and any other payments be paid to the employee? E.g., fortnightly/monthly.","guidance":"

Caution: Some modern awards have clauses dealing with the frequency of payment of wages. The frequency basis set out in this employment contract should be consistent with any requirements under the applicable modern award. 

Guidance: Should a modern award set out the frequency of payments, we recommend inserting the applicable frequency period or “In accordance with the Modern Award”

","questions":[{"name":"SalaryFrequency","label":"Salary frequency","type":"Dropdown","options":[{"id":1,"name":"Weekly"},{"id":2,"name":"Fortnightly"},{"id":3,"name":"Monthly"}]}]},{"title":"Car allowance","header":"Will the employee have a car allowance paid in addition to the Annual Base Salary?","guidance":"

Guidance:  If the employee is entitled to a car allowance under the applicable modern award, and you are paying the employee a grossed-up Annual Base Salary (i.e. the Annual Base Salary compensates the employee for the car allowance entitlement), select NO as this clause provides an entitlement to a payment in addition to the Annual Base Salary.

","questions":[{"name":"HasCarAllowance","label":"Car Allowance","type":"Dropdown","options":[{"id":1,"name":"Yes"},{"id":2,"name":"No"}]}]},{"title":"Car allowance amount","header":"What is the amount of the car allowance?","guidance":"

Guidance:  Some modern awards have clauses which provide for a car allowance. Should the modern award which applies to your employee contain a clause providing a car allowance, and unless you wish to pay a more generous allowance than under the modern award, we recommend that you refer to the car allowance amount as “Calculated in accordance with the Modern Award”.

Typically, this would be expressed as an annual figure. However, this figure could be “per kilometre”, per fortnight or per month.

","questions":[{"name":"CarAllowance","label":"Car Allowance Amount","type":"Custom"}],"dependency":"HasCarAllowance","dependencyValue":"1"},{"title":"Notice period","header":"How much notice will either party be required to provide to the other party if they wish to terminate the employment?","guidance":"

Caution: The National Employment Standards (NES) set out in the Fair Work Act 2009 (Cth) specify the minimum notice period an employer is required to provide of termination.  This will range from between 1-5 weeks, depending on the employee’s length of service and age. We set out the NES notice requirements below:

Employee’s period of continuous service with the employer at the send of the day notice is given Minimum period of notice Minimum period of notice where employee is over 45 years old
Not more than one year1 week1 week
More than one year but not more than 2 years2 weeks2 weeks
At least 2 years but not more than 3 years2 weeks3 weeks
More than 3 years but not more than 5 years3 weeks4 weeks
More than 5 years4 weeks5 weeks

Some enterprise agreements may also deal with the notice that an employee must give to terminate their employment.

","questions":[{"name":"NoticePeriod","label":"Notice period","type":"Custom"}]},{"title":"Access to intranet","header":"Will the employee have access to a copy of the Award and the NES on the Company's intranet?","guidance":"

Guidance: There is no strict legal requirement for an employer to provide access to the modern award or the NES on their intranet site.  However, at a minimum, some modern awards have clauses which require the employer to provide or display a copy of the modern award at the workplace.

","questions":[{"name":"AccessToIntranet","label":"Access to intranet","type":"Dropdown","options":[{"id":1,"name":"Yes"},{"id":2,"name":"No"}]}]},{"title":"Commission scheme","header":"Will the employee be entitled to participate in a company commission scheme (i.e., to receive commission payments based on sales)?","guidance":"

If the employee may be eligible to participate in a Company commission scheme, we recommend that the contract of employment includes a clause dealing with the employee’s eligibility to participate.

","questions":[{"name":"CommissionScheme","label":"Commission scheme","type":"Dropdown","options":[{"id":1,"name":"Yes"},{"id":2,"name":"No"}]}]},{"title":"Bonus scheme","header":"Will the employee be entitled to participate in a company bonus scheme?","guidance":"

Guidance: If the employee may be eligible to participate in a bonus scheme, we recommend that the contract of employment includes a clause dealing with the employee’s eligibility to participate in that scheme. This clause will provide the employer with the maximum flexibility in how it offers a bonus payment to employees, by way of expressly stating that the bonus is a discretionary payment and carving out any contractual entitlement to a bonus.  This is important because in many cases there may be reasons why you may not be able to pay some or all of the bonus payment, including if the bonus is dependent on the profitability of the company. 

","questions":[{"name":"BonusScheme","label":"Bonus scheme","type":"Dropdown","options":[{"id":1,"name":"Yes"},{"id":2,"name":"No"}]}]},{"title":"Post-employment restraint","header":"Do you require any post-employment restraints?","guidance":"

Guidance:–We recommend post-employment restraints where a business has a ‘legitimate business interest to protect’.  A legitimate interest may be confidential information, client or supplier connections or goodwill, among other things.

A valid and enforceable post-employment restraint clause will typically prevent employees from:

    1. Poaching clients;
    2. Providing services to clients
    3. Poaching staff; and
    4. Providing their services to any competing businesses,

following the termination of their employment for a specified period of time in a specified geographic area.

Enforceability: In Australia the common law doctrine of restraint of trade operates only where it does not conflict with the Competition and Consumer Act 2010.  The common law doctrine of restraint of trade renders provisions which impose restrictions on a person's freedom to engage in trade or employment void and therefore unenforceable at common law unless they are demonstrated to bereasonable. & nbsp; The provision must be reasonable both in the interests of the parties and in the interests of the public.& nbsp; A court will consider the reasonableness of a restraint by considering whether it is \"reasonably necessary\" to protect the employer's legitimate business interests e.g. customer connection, confidential information, goodwill and staff connection.  What is reasonable will depend upon the subject matter of the restraint, the time and area of its operation, the nature of the Company's business and the industry in which the Company operates, the relationship of the employee to the Company's clients and customers, and the nature of the work performed by the employee.

If you wish to include a post-employment restraint in your contract of employment, you will need to tailor the period and geographic application of the restraint to each particular employee, in the following section. 

We recommend that you seek legal advice should you have a special business interest to protect.
